text:
The movie is too rushed and lacks character depth. It lacks in showing the contempt between dean Highbottom and Dr. Gaul and rushes through key pieces that show the Snow we've come to hate. 
Many events happen out of order from the book, jumbling the story line. 
Easily the worst Hunger Games adaptation yet.
I cannot stand the fake accent Zegler uses. It’s highly disingenuous.

It was a struggle to like any of the characters. I was hoping they would die just to end the misery. The dialogue was cliche and plot line predictable. I couldn’t make to the end. Nothing compared to the first 3. No star quality - maybe that was it.

I am conflicted here.  There are tons of great elements here - it is well put together and acted, it looks pretty good, even with all the CGI.  The premise was decent, but this is where it get a bit murky.  First of all, the premise is just a remake of the Anakin Skywalker prequels.  And not even that well written.  We KNOW Snow will turn evil, but we want to know how, and this thing was super meandering and ponderous with side plots that didn't matter.  MAYBE it would have been better as a trilogy or a series?  Not sure.  Next up, they TRASHED the original flick... Katniss was supposed to be the bomb, but nope, Snow White did it first and did it best.  Then they lifted characters out of the original - Schwartzman was Tucci, Dinklage was Haymitch, etc.  I wasn't expecting a lot from Zegler, and I think she did ok, but the singing went on way too long and in too many places.  Yeah, this is supposed to be a teeny bopper flick, but geez.
Great distopic movie

Visually appealing. Broken story can be hard to follow. Dialogue not genuine makes it hard to buy into story. A lot of regurgitated ideas from first movies that just seem thrown in. Confusing unbelievable ending. Storyline seems like a bunch of run on ideas thinly sewn together the audience is just expected to keep following. Liked the singing but song lyrics not so much.
story felt uninspired

a highly anticipated one after reading the book, and one that didn’t disappoint. of course there were changes i wished had stayed as they were originally written and of course the pace was super fast due to the time frame, but apart from that i feel like the production, cinematography and casting were simply astonishing! a beautiful movie to watch and appreciate. and the best part is that the special effects were incredibly well done that the movie could easily be one of the best ones ever done from the franchise so far!!! lovely, magnificent and perfectly raw!

I loved this movie, hot take, but I like the camera, how it’s mostly wide shots. I find it way better.  I found it really entertaining before the games during the games after the games, you can tell people saying it’s boring are just in it to see the games ( much like the capital in the original trilogy.) I love the characters and I love the setting, the nature in part III is beautiful There are so many amazing shots and visuals in this movie. It feels so alive. The only thing I have to say is sometimes you can tell that it’s a book, that the writing was from a book but that’s okay. Definitely recommend. it’s a great entry into what’s to come next in the hunger games franchise

I wanna keep it as short as possible.
In comparison to previous movies, this one ain't sh. The only thing I enjoyed is Ms. Viola
Davis of course. The rest they should've kept in the stash. Let's talk about Lucy. Didn't
liked her from very beginning and I don't know who allowed her to sing on the stage
once she was chosen... She literally did nothing on the battlefield. She shouldn't have
won, honestly. And btw, the battlefield was boring, the battle scenes sucked. I get that
it was a long time ago but that probably was their cover to play safe when it comes to
the structure and location of the Hunger Games. The 2nd part of the movie was
extremely boring (couldn't wait the movie to end actually). And I didn't knew that
before Katniss smbd won from District 12 besides Haymitch, and that it was a GIRL who won before? Miss me with this bs. Disappointed. The old movies are so good, but with this prequel they just.... Oh...
The first half was what’s expected of this series. That second half felt so long and mostly pointless. I’m surprised this wasn’t split in to two movies.
It was amasing, it recreated te book perfectly and the cast was great. definitly one of my favourite movie.

It is a prequel to the well-known Panem series. I liked the atmosphere given by the cinematic elements and the character development of the main character, who (expectedly) turned evil although in other ways some characters and plot points seemed quite flat. 
All in all: wouldn't miss it if I didn't watch though it was quite interesting to do so.

The Hunger Games is one of my favorite book series and I have completely enjoyed every movie up until this point. I wanted to love it, I really did. The movie strayed too much from the book, omitted crucial points, changed character deaths, changed Lucy Grays personality, sped through her and Snows relationship to the point that it felt unlikely. I feel like if a movie is made from a book, it should atleast convey the message intended by the author and I found this movie lacking at no fault of the actors at all. Disappointed.

It started off really well, drew me in immediately. Then I saw Rachel Zegler but kept it on, then they all started singing. Turned it off. Nothing against singing but I don't know this character, she may be your strong female lead but you have to build up to it. Rest of the film might be great, or it might, pathetically have a turn of events of her being a "spectacle" by singing, and I'm not wasting my time to find out.

It was very boring
Not my favorite movie
Hours of my life I will never get back ,
Terrible just terrible

This movie is much different from the book. In the book, Snow is not portrayed as a benevolent saint, as he is in the film. I also feel that the relationship between Lucy and Snow is rushed. I loved the first three movies and books, which are closely related, but this film strays too far from the source material, particularly in regards to Snow's character. Sejanus is depicted as more compassionate than Snow in the books, yet he comes across as a whiny brat in the movie, and their roles are literally switched in some scenes. They were not as friendly towards each other as the film suggests. Snow resents Sejanus most of the time.

While I believe the cast is great, Lucy is not Katniss; she (Lucy) is much kinder and more lovable in the book and does not try so hard to fit the interpretation that Zegler presents. However, I acknowledge that the books revolve around Snow's thoughts, and it's challenging to convey those thoughts without a narrator. On a positive note, I really love the set design and costume work; the Capitol looks fantastic!
